problem.p: Parts have already been partially processed before they reach a certain shop. When a part enters the shop, the company has already spent $10,000 for both raw material and previous processing. More processing is required before they can be sold or assembled onto a final product.

In that shop, machine \(M\) takes one minute to do an operation. It costs $500 to do that operation. The machine is always operational, but it has a probability 0.1 of creating a defective part. In other words, a part that is operated on by M has probability 0.1 of being unacceptable and probability 1-0.1 of being acceptable.

If the operation on it is good, the cost-based value of the part is $10,000+$500. That is, its value has increased by $500. If the operation is bad, the part must be scrapped and its market value is 0. (In that case, the company has lost $10,500 since it the money spent on the operation was lost.)
problem.label: What is the expected value of a part when it leaves the shop? (This includes both good and bad parts.)
What is the expected increase of a part's value due to the operation? (It's possible for this value to be negative)
What is the production rate of good parts?

div.p: The value of the part is $10,500 with probability 0.9 and 0 with probability 0.1. Thus the expected value is just \($10,500*0.9\).

The expected value of the part has increased by \($10,500*0.9-$10,000\). Note, it is possible for the part to lose value due to an operation if the probability of defect is large and the cost of the second operation is small.
Since the operation time is only 1 minute, the production rate is just 1-0.1.
